name: Hammer
short_description: Single candle with small body and long lower shadow signaling bottom reversal.
definition: The Hammer is a candlestick pattern with bullish bias, commonly observed in trend reversal scenarios. Single candle with small body and long lower shadow signaling bottom reversal. Traders use this pattern to anticipate potential upward price movement when confirmed with volume and price action.
anatomy: Single candle with distinctive body and shadow proportions. Single candle with small body and long lower shadow signaling bottom reversal. The pattern is identified by its characteristic shape and the market context in which it appears.
confirmation_rules: Price closes above the pattern's high on confirmation candle
Volume increases on the bullish confirmation
Pattern forms at a known support level or demand zone
RSI shows bullish divergence or exits oversold territory
Moving average support nearby adds confluence
invalidation_rules: Price closes below the pattern's low invalidates the setup
No bullish follow-through within 2-3 candles
Volume dries up after the pattern forms

best_timeframes.rationale: Most reliable on daily charts with clear trend context
Good for swing trade entries and exits
Useful for intraday timing at key levels
Scalping only; higher noise and lower reliability

best_context: Most effective at horizontal support, rising trendlines, or Fibonacci retracement levels after a sustained downtrend. Volume expansion on the pattern and confirmation increases reliability.
quick_checklist: Pattern forms at support or demand zone
Confirmation candle closes above key level
Check for higher timeframe trend alignment
common_traps: Trading before confirmation leads to premature entries
Pattern at minor support can fail easily
Strong downtrend may overwhelm bullish signals
Low volume patterns often fail
Confusing similar patterns leads to false reads
Multiple patterns without follow-through = stay out

Hammer pattern on MSFT 4H chart — single candle with small body and long lower shadow signaling bottom reversal
Hammer pattern on GOOGL 1H chart — single candle with small body and long lower shadow signaling bottom reversal

short_description: Three symmetrical pushes to a high with harmonic ratios.
definition: The Three Drives (Bearish) is a chart pattern pattern with bearish bias, commonly observed in trend reversal scenarios. Three symmetrical pushes to a high with harmonic ratios. Traders use this pattern to anticipate potential downward price movement when confirmed with volume and price action.
anatomy: Forms over multiple candles/bars creating a recognizable geometric structure. Three symmetrical pushes to a high with harmonic ratios. The pattern is identified by its characteristic shape and the market context in which it appears.
confirmation_rules: Price closes below the pattern's low on confirmation candle
Volume increases on the bearish confirmation
Pattern forms at a known resistance level or supply zone
RSI shows bearish divergence or exits overbought territory
Breakdown below key moving average adds confirmation
invalidation_rules: Price closes above the pattern's high invalidates the setup
No bearish follow-through within 2-3 candles
Volume dries up after the pattern forms

best_timeframes.rationale: Most reliable on daily charts with clear trend context
Good for swing trade entries and exits
Useful for intraday timing at key levels
Scalping only; higher noise and lower reliability

best_context: Most effective at horizontal resistance, declining trendlines, or Fibonacci extension levels after a sustained uptrend. Volume expansion confirms distribution.
quick_checklist: Pattern forms at resistance or supply zone
Confirmation candle closes below key level
Check for higher timeframe trend alignment
common_traps: Trading before confirmation leads to premature entries
Pattern at minor resistance can fail easily
Strong uptrend may overwhelm bearish signals
Low volume patterns often fail
Confusing similar patterns leads to false reads
Short squeezes can invalidate bearish setups quickly

name: ABCD (Bullish)
short_description: Four-point pattern with two equal legs and Fibonacci ratios.
definition: The ABCD (Bullish) is a chart pattern pattern with bullish bias, commonly observed in trend reversal scenarios. Four-point pattern with two equal legs and Fibonacci ratios. Traders use this pattern to anticipate potential upward price movement when confirmed with volume and price action.
anatomy: Forms over multiple candles/bars creating a recognizable geometric structure. Four-point pattern with two equal legs and Fibonacci ratios. The pattern is identified by its characteristic shape and the market context in which it appears.
confirmation_rules: Price closes above the pattern's high on confirmation candle
Volume increases on the bullish confirmation
Pattern forms at a known support level or demand zone
RSI shows bullish divergence or exits oversold territory
Moving average support nearby adds confluence
invalidation_rules: Price closes below the pattern's low invalidates the setup
No bullish follow-through within 2-3 candles
Volume dries up after the pattern forms

best_timeframes.rationale: Most reliable on daily charts with clear trend context
Good for swing trade entries and exits
Useful for intraday timing at key levels
Scalping only; higher noise and lower reliability

best_context: Most effective at horizontal support, rising trendlines, or Fibonacci retracement levels after a sustained downtrend. Volume expansion on the pattern and confirmation increases reliability.
quick_checklist: Pattern forms at support or demand zone
Confirmation candle closes above key level
Check for higher timeframe trend alignment
common_traps: Trading before confirmation leads to premature entries
Pattern at minor support can fail easily
Strong downtrend may overwhelm bullish signals
Low volume patterns often fail
Confusing similar patterns leads to false reads
Multiple patterns without follow-through = stay out
